data.title: Out of the shadows: a biographical history of African American athletes 1557288267, 9781557288264
data.meta_description: The original essays in this comprehensive collection examine the lives and sports of famous and not-so- famous African A...
data.text:
Table of contents :

Contents......Page 8

Preface......Page 12

I. Striving for Athletic Success in a Jim Crow Society......Page 14

1. Jimmy Winkfield: The “Black Maestro” of the Racetrack......Page 20

2. Marshall “Major” Taylor: The Fastest Bicycle Riderin the World......Page 34

3. The Strange Career of William Henry Lewis......Page 52

4. Jack Johnson and the Quest for Racial Respect......Page 72

II. Fashioning a World of Sport behind Segregated Walls and on the International Stage......Page 86

5. Ora Washington: The First Black Female Athletic Star......Page 92

6. Satchel Paige’s Struggle for Selfhood in the Era of Jim Crow......Page 106

7. Jesse Owens: Leading Man in Modern American Talesof Racial Progress and Limits......Page 124

8. Joe Louis, Boxing, and American Culture......Page 146

9. Alice Coachman: Quiet Champion of the 1940s......Page 160

10. Jackie Robinson: Racial Pioneer and AthleteExtraordinaire in an Era of Change......Page 176

III. The Fight for Civil Rights through Athletic Performance, Persuasion, and Protest......Page 194

11. “Jackie Robinson without the Charm” : The Challenges of Being Althea Gibson......Page 200

12. Wilma Rudolph: The Making of an Olympic Icon......Page 220

13. Bill Russell: Pioneer and Champion of the Sixties......Page 236

14. Jim Brown: Superlative Athlete, Screen Star, Social Activist......Page 254

15. Muhammad Ali: Flawed Rebel with a Cause......Page 276

16. “The Quiet Militant” : Arthur Ashe and Black Athletic Activism......Page 292

IV. Race, Sport, and Celebrity Culture......Page 310

17. Bound by Blackness or Above It? Michael Jordan and theParadoxes of Post–Civil Rights American Race Relations......Page 314

18. “Race,” Family, and Nation: The Significance ofTiger Woods in American Culture......Page 338

19. “Ghetto Cinderellas” : Venus and Serena Williamsand the Discourse of Racism......Page 366

Notes......Page 386

Bibliographical Note......Page 442

Contributors......Page 452

Index......Page 458
